Tasted in blind tasting with 13 other gueuzes, this one placed 5.Murky orange colour. Aroma has rather nice sourness with earthy notes and farmhouse. Flavour contains also very nice sourness with earthy notes and some spices. Good and balanced gueuze!

37,5 cl bottle vintage 2000@ Tammela vintage tasting, BBE 2020
Almost no CO2 at all. Mostly gueuze-like but also some vinegar in the taste. Not bad but not worth ageing this much. Harsh score estimate: 3.6.
Strong fruitiness in aroma as well as some barnyard/mustiness.  The flavor is very tart with some musty/barnyard elements.  Still relatively new to lambics, this one was pretty good.

75cl bottle. Pours a hazy orange color with a white head. The aroma is intense. Cheese, hay, mold, must. Taste is sweet and tart, really tart. It starts like liquid hay and moves to tart fruit and must, mold, leather and barnyard. Good carbonation and medium body. Overall, a fantastic gueuze.

Pizzeria Paradiso, Dupont, DC 10oz cask ($5hh): Pours a light brownish, amberish color without any head because of the cask pour. Aroma is vinegar and a whole lot of funk. I suppose there are apples and cheese and some other things, but mostly we can refer to that as the funk. In any case taste is pretty sour. Very little sweetness. Mostly just a somewhat complex and ever-changing taste in which there is plenty to savor. Cheezy, yeasty, and overall quite good. This is the first beer I was warned about before I ordered it. I guess some people cant handle your funk.
Dark blonde, small head, some bubbles. Aroma is sour, green apples, grapefruit. Sour taste, bitter, full bodied, intense, dry, fresh, until now the most intense oude gueuze I had. very nice!
Bottle, pours a nice foamy head with a nice sour smell. Taste is a nice sourness with a good tartness. good blend
Sampled at an ESBLS tasting.  No head on this one and the beer is hazy, dingy and golden.  Flavors are nice fruit, yeast, barnyard funk, and light vinegar.  This was nice.

375, corked and baled. Pours a murky dark orange with no head or lace to speak of. Ripping funky nose, showing oranges, strawberries, and a big methane-rich blast of sweaty-saddle barnyard. Creamy medium body with soft carb. Tangy orange and strawberry mid-palate with somewhat subdued funk compared to the nose. Rather thin and watery in both body and flavor profile.

Pours a slightly cloudy orange, some bubbles floating around. Smells like sour patch kids and stomach acid? Tasted aggressively of sour fruit with high acidity and had a lingering dry/tangy finish. Truly a wild brew and a great sipper nonetheless.

A dusty bottle from Nelson Wines. It pours hazy golden yellow, with pretty much no head. The nose is farmyard, wheat, cinnamon, nutmeg, sour apple and chamomile. The taste is tart lemon, sour green apple, white grape, orange pith, light spice and warming alcohol, with a long tangy-tart finish. Medium body and fine carbonation. Juicy tartness, well balanced and complex.

on draft cask condition at the thirsty monk.  copper color no head, sour, wet wool, lemon grass, dirt, earthy rolled into one for a complex tasting beer that is tart on the front as well as the end. very rich in flavors. first time trying this one and very happy that i did.

Golden brown, with almost no head. Aroma is sour, acid, wood.
Taste is like the aroma, moderate to heavy sour, citrus fruit sour. Notes of wood, leaves a sour taste in the throat. Quite an impressive gueuze compared to Cantillon for example.Bottle was not more then one year old.
Bottle purchased in Brugge. Poured light golden yellow with little head. Aroma is of a light sourness. Flavour was extremely sour with light yeast notes, which I enjoyed.

750.  Pours a fairly clear light orange with little head.  Aromas are a nice mix of barn, lemon and tartness with a little bit of nectarine pit and grapefruit.  Flavor is very lovely as well.  Its not quite as complex as I would hope, but it is very nice.  Theres a bit more sugar than I expected, but the sour is still enough to fulfill some of my cravings at the moment.  Good stuff!
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
Lot H. 375ml corked and caged bottle. Served slightly chilled into a tulip glass. Grabbed this bottle straight from the box the day it arrived. Interesting note....the bottles were shipped on their sides interlocking with each other. There was zero wrap or protection around them. Scary!

A - A nice copper apple juice colored body. Small white head which settled into some edging. I was able to get a crystal clear pour and swirled the last ounce or so into a snifter.

S - Very funky and brett forward. Sour apples and lemon peel, hay, grass, yeast, and a strong funky burn. Towards the end there is a slightly off-putting fecal/chemical aroma.

T - Super tart and acidic. Ripe sour green apples and lemon juice. Funky hay and barnyard flavors. This is rather intense and harsh, which I personally enjoy. You can feel your taste buds being obliterated, but that taste and tartness keeps me coming back for more. Really great balance between fruit and funk. The mouth feel is crisp and lively, but the finish is really intense and biting.

O - This is a very acidic and intense gueze. Cantillon and Drie Fonteinen both bring the funk, but they do so in a much classier and elegant way. Perhaps its due to its freshness, but this is extremely tart and acidic at this point. Load of sour apple and lemons. Im sure with some more age it smooths out a bit into something that can compete with the big guys. A fantastic beer.

Gold, white vanishing head.  Aroma is sour, sewage, and funk.  Body is very light, crisp, and carbonated.  Flavor is very lactic and sour, no hop bitterness, slight apple.  tasted side-by-side with Oud-Beersel and Cantillon Guezes.  All three had the same appearance, this one had more funky/sewage notes, less fruity notes in the aroma, and less bitterness in the flavor, although it was amazing how similar they tasted.

This first gueuze experience (Drie Fonteinen Doesjel ) wasnt so great so Im hoping this is better. This beer pours a cloudy bright copper in color with a light, white lacing around the glass. It smells of fermented peaches, has some funk but what I would describe as a lot, and also features a mild tartness, and light alcohol. The flavors are much better than in my first gueuze experience. You actually get some fruit. It instantly bites your tongue with peach skin like tartness. Its almost the perfect amount of sour. It has light funk and wasnt heavy on sediment whatsoever. Perhaps the biggest difference is the mouthfeel. It has a nice crisp bite to it. I really like it. Im glad I tried this so it gives me better prospective on the style. Now, on to the next one.

Appearance is dark gold, clear, little head.  Aroma is sour hay, green apple, and lemon.  Taste is quite sour with funky hay and apple notes.  Body is medium, sticky, highly carbonated, and somehow a dry finish.  Overall, this is middle of the road as far as lambics go, Ive had better and Ive had worse but I have a definite soft spot for this style.

Pours hazy darker gold with a small white head which dissipated quickly.  Aroma is sour, earthyness, musty and woody.  Taste is tart with a sweet citrus finish.  Dry and crisp, very nice.  As it warmed the funkyness increased.
Golden yellow colour. Smells sour, wine and corky. Tastes sour, balanced. Its a good gueuze beer, but takes a few sips to get used to. Good mouthfeel.

Bottle @ home shared with DutchDrebus. Clear yellow color, small white head. Sour smell mixed with something weird, dont know what it is. Nice balanced sour taste, dry finish. Pretty decent beer. Ok carbo, medium body.

Corked and caged, green glass.  Have had this bottle for at least two years.  Pours orange-tinged deep golden, a lacing creamy white head.  Smells metallic and sour and acidic, and freaking intense.  Taste, wow, mouth puckeringly sour, burns but from the acidity rather than the alcohol.  Lemon (heavy, heavy citrus) behind the metal and mixing with some barnyard.  Saliva production activated in earnest.  Touches of wood and wheat, touch of spice, aftertaste is akin to a sour Wit but with woody dryness and a lingering fruitiness.  Full body, bone dry, refreshing.  For sourheads, revelatory, and I think very underrated on here.

Opaque gold with a nice white head that quickly diminishes.  A strong aroma of funky goodies greats the nostrils: rotten peaches, lemon rind, pepper, damp soil, earthy mushrooms.  A perfect body of tart citrus flows and folds into peppery peaches, day old lime juice, and a little herbal bitterness.  Finishes with a lingering taste of earthy lime.  Fantastic gueuze that would pare well with something light and sweet: dried fruit, coconut cream pie.

Bottle 37,5 cl a cloudy orange amber beer with low head. Nose is typical lambic with wet moss notes and woody. Aroma is very dry, cheese like, bit sour, slightly acid, banana notes, ground notes. Not exceptional anyway.

Bottle. Pours orange gold with quick whitish head and lots of effervescence. I immediately smell peach and brettanomyces funk while Im still pouring; a closer whiff reveals a deep fruitiness with peach, citrus, pear, strawberry, and sour grapes, along with lots of dank musty cellar character, a touch of oak, and young cheese. The flavor is assertively tart with a nice edgy acidity. A mild fruitiness is quite obvious, something like store-bought fruit cocktail, but without the gross syrup. The finish is more musty than sour, with a dank farm/hay quality. It lingers into the aftertaste as the fruitiness and acidity fade. The aftertaste is like a young creamy cheese, maybe along the lines of camambert. quite a satisfying gueuze.
Bottle. Hazy golden/orange with medium off-white head. Flavour is malt, wheat, tart, citrus, sour, little barnyard and oak.

Bottle, courtesy of yngwie.Pours golden with a white head. Aroma of ripe apples, lemon, musty funk, basement and grapes.Flavor is sour with some sweetness, lemon, leather, oak, berries and funk.Medium body, average carbonation.Nice sour and funky beer.

Tasted on 7/12/11 from a 375mL bottle purchased at Binnys Hyde Park.  Pours cloudy light orange with a thick, fluffy white head that recedes rather quickly to nothing more than a collar of lace.  The nose is super acidic and sour with a ton of lemon, a light dose of brett barnyard funk, a bit of fruity vinegar, along with very light cinnamon spices and vanilla from the use of oak.  The flavor is very sour and lemon acidic up front, moving to some hay malt flavors, brett barnyard, light vinegar, and oaky vanilla and just a hint of cinnamon.  The body is medium and very textured with average carbonation and a long tannic, lemon acidic and vanilla oak finish.
Pours yellow with a white head.  Smells of sweat, funky, peachy, tarte, acidic.  Taste is on the mellow side with some funky bites and a lemony finish.

375ml bottle.
Clear, medium gold, thin white head.
The aroma is very funky, lots of Brett, straw, yeast.
Bone dry, medium body, low bitternerness, balanced CO2.
Very acidic taste, funky, straw, hay, apples. Surprisingly clean for Hanssens? (2011-05-12)

AROMA: bread, dough

APPEARANCE: golden, clear, minimal head

TASTE: light sweetness, heavily sour

PALATE: light body, creamy, fizzy, astringent, long finish

OVERALL: not my cup of tea, but I can appreciate it

Saures, tonangebendes Aroma, dabei fruchtig-spritzig, der saure Ton bleibt bestehen. Es wirkt sehr abgerundet und wird noch saurer, daneben etwas würzig. Komplexes, aber ausgewogenes Bier. 	 
Test vom 30.5.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 11,13,12,13,8,13 - 12,40

Bottle. Opens with a nice little pop and poured into a tulip glass. Clear, medium amber orange color with a white collared head. Lemon, grape, slight funk in the aroma. Starts with a white wine grape sweetness that then transitions to a lemon zest like note. Building sourness. Ends wtih a slightly funky finish. Light mouthfeel. Nice carbonation. Overall, decent but not sure it is worth the price.

30/05/2011 37.5cl bottle @ home - BB: 7/8/2027 (2011-240)  
Note: as best before date is usually set 20 years after bottling, this one must have been about 4 years old.
Clear orange coloured beer, light beige creamy head, pretty stable and adhesive. Aroma: lemon and lime, just a little touch of basement, a bit peppery. MF: good carbon, medium body. Taste: surprisingly bitter start, very earthy, wood and tobacco, then sour comes kicking in, vinegar. Aftertaste: very fruity with touches of lime, pineapple, tangerine, oranges. Very surprising contrast between taste and aftertaste.
Not for beginners!  Funky turnipy woody, tart dry finish, flat feel b/c its on cask, unique even within the gueze style.

Poured from a bottle at Hanssens Artisanaal. Apricot coloured body with a slight haze. Patchy surface. Aroma of tart fruits. Acid fruits in flavour added by dark spices. Dry and sour in a lingering tail. Refreshing (Toer de Geuze, Dworp, 01.05.2011).
Truly a sour beer.  Upon opening it stinks a bit like urine.  It is very dry, almost champagne like.  Sour apples come to mind when tasting this.  Just not my beer.

Small offwhite head. Hazy opaque yellow body. Waxy earthy funky barnyard aroma with lemony notes. Sweetish-dry sour fruity waxy earthy taste. Mid-bodied. Sharp mouthfeel. Sharply sour lemony earthy vinegary aftertaste. Very hard to describe and analyze. Clean, fresh geuze with more sweetness than most. (Taster at the brewery.)

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2013 Draft at RnH with Linh. Pours an amber body with no head, completely flat. Aroma is funky feet, tart fruit, and lots of vinegar. Mouthfeel is tart with notes of fruit and vinegar. Definitely Grew on me.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2011 On tap at the map room; pour is honey golden with a modest white head that rims the glass with large bubbles, which is interesting, because they dont seem to dissipate. Aromas are barnyard, citrus, apple rinds, florals, lemon grass; this is a fantastic brew on the tongue; there is a distinct earthiness present here, combined with a tart, funky, fantastic lambic feel. This is probably the best gueuze Ive had thus far. (which isnt saying much)

Found this one bottled at Binnys in St. Charles, Illinois.  Intrigued by the style, and found this to be the only one carried at my local beer store.  Cloudy, dark yellow pour with a thick, one-finger eggshell head.  Nose smells just like pee.  Unfortunate.  Powerfully dry, earthy, and slightly floral, but tartness pervades this beer.  Puckeringly dry finish.  To say I didnt like it would be overstating it, but this just isnt my beer.

375 ml bottle poured into a tulip. Pours a glowing darker golden hue moving into sunset orange, a decent haze, with decent sized bright white head that dies to a film, ok lacing. Aromas are powerful, rubber and barnyard funk, manure, and horseblanket moving into sour lemons and lactic acid, wet oak peeks through, some yogurt and stinky cheese. A distinct funky brett and barnyard dominance with secondary lemons, rubber, lemonade, lactic acid, bread dough and flaked wheat. Potent on the nose, warmth brings out straw and bigger citrusy sour fruit elements, some crab apple, and pineapple. Initial is lighter bodied, sharper sour fruits and lemons mingle with wet oak, lactic acid and yogurt, bread dough moving into a smaller funky brett presence than the nose let on. Straw, horsenblanket, and dry funkiness moves into a dry and sour acidic finish with some cool yogurt, vanilla and wet oak, with further sour lemons, lactic acid. Touches of crab apple, some light spiciness. Light carbonation gives it a touch of life on the palate, potent sourness. Very nice, maybe a bit strong on the acidity, but I dug it. It wasnt the most complex of the style, but offered what I was looking for - a powerful sour, more fruit slanted gueuze. On the fence lovers of stronger sour beers need not apply.
Hazy orange, almost looks like a hefeweizen.  Sour in the nose, flavor is reminiscent of a barnyard with a refreshing sourness.  Funky and acidic....very acidic.  An excellent gueuze.

Cask, Churchkey. Hazy burnt marigold with no head. Metallic and minerally aroma with some funk in the aroma.  Dusty, light funk, metal, slight leather and the acidity hits hard on the back of the throat. Medium body, slick, and subtle carbonation.
Cask @ ginger man nyc. Brown with no head. Smells of fruit, cherries and apples. Taste is tart, sour and sweet. Puckering aftertase. Really interestinh and complex. Really good

Bottle sampled at the 2nd Annual Sour Town tasting on 4/23/11. Clear gold/amber pour with a thin white head. Nose is of sourness and peppery yeast. Sour flavor on the tongue with some peppery character and a citrusy, tangy sour finish.

Bottle 37,5 cl from www.erzbierschof.ch. Clear orangy beer, fine white foam, sparkling. Aromas of apple, cider, acid, sulfur, a certain roundness. The taste is acid but round, in cider and pineapple. It is prickly, very fruity, vinegar, balsamic and astringent. Final long, perfumed, fresh, woody and hints of rhubarb.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2016 375 ml bottle.
Pours a golden colour with a long-lasting white head. Loads of lazy visible bubbles. Aroma of mild barnyard, strong vinegar and some sweet fruits. Flavour was surprisingly tart with an instant sour hit to the mouth with peach, green apples and especially oak. Mouthdrying acidic sour finish. Medium bodied with a thick mouthfeel and some carbonation as well. Refreshing and tasty. Top-notch.

Vintage tasting (2000 + 2010). The 2000 vintage is near vinegar, when the 2010 version is near perfection. Just enough tartness with heavy jammy notes. Great!
8oz pour @ Fountainhead on Cask. Dark orange cloudy pour no head. A bit of a funk aroma. Light and easy mouthfeel. A yeasty doughy lasting taste and a pleasnt sour finish, that lasts. Enjoyable.
A lambic for the adventurous. Both the nose and taste are very sweet and tarty. Taste is similar to that of a very sweet fruit tart. Slightly puckering

Bottle:
Very small white head/lacing on top of a hazy yellow/orange beer.
Smell yeast and sour an a hint of wood. 
Taste sour, yeast, yoghurt sour, wood, green apple, hint of sweet and citric, spices, light peppery.
Sour and a light sweet aftertaste.
Medium carbo, medium to full body, tingly mouthfeel. Another lovely gueuze!
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text:
Relatively new to sours, gueuze, and lambics.  From what Ive studied up on it appears that this gueuze is one of the finest.

Aroma:  The sour, funky character of this gueuze are instantly noticeable to the nose.  I also picked up scents of apricots and peaches, however only slightly.
Appearance:  Golden, straw-colored appearance.  Slight head that dissipated quickly.  Little to no lacing, drinking out of a snifter.
Taste:  Extremely sour and funky.  I can pick up notes of fruit but not much sweetness from them.  The sour/tartness here reminds me of the sourness that comes from a warhead (candy).
Mouthfeel:  Very sharp, crisp, and carbonated.  This beer has a fizzling effect on my tongue and a puckering effect on my cheeks.  
Overall:  Enjoyed greatly.  Not an everyday beer, but thats what makes it special.  Did not pair with any food, although it could be interesting with creamy dishes that the sourness could cut through.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2011 Aroma is lots of lemon, tart citrus, some vinegar, some funk.  Pours slightly hazy golden with minimal head and lacing.  Flavor is tart fruits, some cheesy hops, lemon, vinegar.  Palate is dry, light body, moderately puckering. Very nice.
Very nice gueuze with a very nice scent and a very nice taste. Love the sourness.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2013 Time for a re-rate, had this quite a few times since the previous rating. 375 ml. bottle @ home. Procured from Willems. No clear date. Hazy darker geuze orange, white head that doesnt last. Huge horseblanket as I remember, biggest horseblanket of all geuzes, lemon, tart, old barrel, leon sourness, tang, slight kids aspirin. Tastes of sour, tangy lemon, huge horseblanket, lingering sourness, sharp new wood, lemon acidity, childrens aspirin. Pretty brutal acidity, this has never been as hardcore as the other Hanssens but it is still harsh. Keep in mind this is good sourness, not USA Vinegar masked as beer. Big carb. in a good way. These days, no,-aged, fresh, regular lambics this is my favourite, better than Cantillon & a guarantee of a splendid bottle unlike 3F which varies from good to oh lord. Girardin seems to have slipped. Increased score again from 4.8 to 4.9. This is the max. hopefully no hype will ever come.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */: sour lemons & grapefruit as well as some sweet fruits, accompanied by plenty of tart, slightly acidic, minor funk, lots of wild yeast, puling the flavours towards it, as usual really dry, enough carbonation // drank 2 more 75 cl.s that I picked up at the brewery - first beer I would say really tastes like diaper - whatever that means - lovely // tried this one gain, prefere it over Girardin one these days, lots of stuff going on here, way more on the very heavy funk side this one as opposed  the other stuff which is heavily sour, good but crazy sour /// uped it from 4.7 to 4.8

Had a 375ml bottle served at about 55.  Poured a hazy orange and the head dissipated quickly.  Smells incredibly sour with a suble hint of sulfur; almost like vinegar.  The sourness and dryness suck all the moisture out of your mouth.  Tastes like the first second when you put a sweet tart in your mouth; all tart and no sweetness.  Great beer, but only for the adventurous.

375ml green corked and caged bottle. I honestly cant figure out the vintage.

IT pours a honey gold, a very nice color with a fizzy soapy white head that leaves walls of lacing all the way around the glass.

Off the bat it is noticeable tart in the smell. After the initial sour cringe it is nicely subtle with a few different scents in play. It has mostly an acidic smell with lemons and vinegar, but there is a noticeable funky must to it that may remind one of an old closet or an open field that has been inhabited by cattle. There is just a bit of grain in the smell along with some very faint vanilla notes.

The flavor continues with the tartness, though it is more in the mid-palate than up front or in the aftertaste. It has almost a lemony plastic flavor to it at first, which I found odd, but after a few more sips the plastic fades and the acidic lemon stays. There is an adequate amount of malt present in the flavor. It is a dry beer but there a thick enough mouthfeel to give the slightest bit of caramel characteristics to the malt bill. It also has an almost tea-like characteristic. Some oxidized green apple comes through as it warms. It is a very clean tasting Gueuze, though there is some funk, it just seems that even though it is wild, it is also quite symmetrical.

A very nice beer.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-28-2011 05:33:26

750ml, Probably fresh and basically at room temperature - Pours a golden, yellowish with a frothy pure white head that lasts and lasts.  Aroma is fruity, sour, tart, acidity, funk, horseblanket, and citrusy/lemons.  Taste is semi-sweet at first, then quickly becomes sharply tart and moves to sour.  Its so sour it begins to burn your tongue and mouth - you can lick the sourness off your lips.  It ends with a very long-lasting funky, lactic/acidic aftertaste.  Very refreshing and zesty.  Can easily imagine myself enjoying this at a cafe in Brussels on a fantastic warm summer nite.

12.7oz bottle. Orange brown pour, hazy and cloudy. Slight spotty lacing. A lot of sour funk in the aroma, with hints of lemon citrus zest. Good amount of sour in the flavor, thats about it. Simply amazing though.

As with all Gueuzes, Hanssens is a mixture of several vintages to produce a lambic which is refreshingly fruity.

This is the result of blending different lambics of different ages. The second fermentation takes place inside the bottles and therefore they are stored for minimum six months in constant temperature kept cellars.

750ml bottle from K&L.  Pours a bright but slightly hazy golden color with a nice lacey one finger white head.  Great aroma, big and funky with pale malt notes, quite a bit of barnyard.  Pretty nice gueuze flavor, nice pale malt base with big barnyard funk and average sourness.  Just a hint of sweetness to it.  Nice mouthfeel, medium bodied and very tingly with high carbonation.  A good gueuze overall, and the best Ive had from Hanssens.

Pours brilliantly clear gold with no head. Just a ring of fine bubbles. Aroma is huge barnyard, with a cheesy funk to it. Slight dark fruit aroma in the background. Body is thin, almost watery. Flavor is sharply sour funk w/ slight cherry, or plum notes in the backgroung with slightly sweet finish, and aftertaste. Very good, but not as great as I expected.

375ml bottle shared by MartinT. Bottle was about 6-7 years old.
Appearance : Hazy pale yellow with a medium head.

Aroma : Acidic and a bit lactic. Nice tartness, nice green apples and white grapes. Light notes of wet wood.

Taste : Nice sourness and tartness. A bit lactic and quite acidic. A bit woody. Finish is quite acidic. Dry and woody finish.

Overall : Very complex nose and taste. Maybe a bit more complex than the Drie Fonteinen Gueuze. Nice wood and fruity notes. Nice tartness. Still a bit too acidic for my taste. I prefer Drie Fonteinen and Girardin. Far less drinkable than the others.

Bottle, 37,5 cl. Golden coloured beer with nearly no head. Aroma is nicely fruity and sour. Taste goes with the aroma: fruity and a clearly present sour, tart taste. The taste doesnt change, so no great pallet, but for a good Gueuze like this one I dont complain about it..

Bottle.  Golden in color with a nice white head.  Funky nose.  I really like it to be honest.  Mouth puckering acetic character.  Really liked this, but the sour characteristic overpowered everything else in the the flavor to me.

Appearance is a copper color with a lasting white head. The nose is a complex funkness with a huge lemon, barnyard scent. In addition is a tartness that doesnt leave the nose. Taste follows. I like it, a lot...

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2013 Bottle vintage 2005 =. 3,8 (2013-10-26)

Bottle from Craked Kettle, cons 2011-01-08 Göteborg
AR: wet horse blanket, strawberries???
AP: bronz colored body, wee shite head
F: sour full body, malt vineager, dry finish,

Smells like salami.  Hot dogs and ketchup.  Salty.  Big mouth feel.  It was incredibly fun to offer a whiff and a taste to everyone at New Years Eve.  The most bizarre, funky, sour, salty thing Ive put in my mouth.  Im thoroughly impressed, but dont know if Ill be buying it again soon.  I will remember this beer as something to taste every five years to see how far Ive come towards the development of a perversely sophisticated palate.

Pours a bright yellow with a towering white head and a good amount of lacing. Nose is incredibly funky, near the most funk and earth that Ive ever encountered. No need for sourness when theres this much barnyard going on. The taste is a bit overwhelming, even though I love this stuff. Just super raw and pungent. Nice dry mouthfeel with good carbonation. Drinkability is a bit toward the low end given the sheer magnitude of the flavor and the fact that its fairly one dimensional.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-24-2010

Thanks bvc!  Tarnished gold in the glass, good carbonation.  Sharp lemon aroma over oak.  Maybe its a little turned down from other Gueuzes I love, though its so magically sublime and sessionable I enjoy it on a different level.  Thorough funk is restrained in intensity.

Bottle at Where the Wild Beers Are. Hazy golden pour. Aroma of strawberry, lemon, and a bit of soap. Less soap in the flavor: more tart strawberry and lemon flavors with only a slight funkiness. Moderate tart lingering. Solid.

This is my first gueuze so Im not speaking from experience.  Definite sour aroma and really didnt get much else.   Beautiful crystal clear golden yellow with a very thin but persistent white lacing.  Sour and earthy with tanned leather notes.  A woodsy flavor in the background and in the aftertaste.  Very interesting and not overpowering, and also quite refreshing.
Tasted from a 375 mL bottle purchased in Kansas City, Missouri.  Medium, hazy orange appearance.  Big sour aroma like a typical Gueuze.  Sweet and sour flavor.  Pretty good Gueuze.

Serving: 375 ml. bottle from State Line Liquors. 
Aroma: The nose is a fairly strong tart note with a little cider, some barnyard, and light florals. 
Appearance: It pours a cloudy, light orange with a foamy white head.  The head leaves nice lacing. 
Taste: The flavor is sour from start to finish.  It has great balance though with nice yeast notes, hay, florals, tangy malt, a bit of earth, and citrus peel. 
Palate: Light in body with high carbonation leading to a dry, clean finish. 
Overall: I really liked this one end to end and highly recommend it if you are a gueuze fan.

Bottle. Pours hazy orange with a light, off-white head. Orange citrus, acidic and woody aroma. Fairly sweet, citric with sour fruits. Light to medium in body with lively carbonation. Finishes very dry with lingering sourness. Very good.
Very tart. Flavors consist of a combination of lemon, black peppers, grapes, grass, banana, tangerine,  and black cherry. Good with Gouda.

Funky cider vinegar aroma. Hazy amber, effervescent. Nice mouthfeel with just the right amount of carbonation for the acidity leve. Apple and apple core flavor. Subtle must which is more pronounced in the finish but still light. Very drinkable and not overly sour. Good and well done, but unspectacular.

Hazy golden pour.  The nose also has a kiss of pineapple and a bit of acetone as well.  The nose has a little bit of earthiness.  Some fruit and a bit of light sweetness.  A bit of some light funk.  As it warms, it opens up a bit.  Soft palate and a touch of light fruitiness as well.  This goes back and forth from nicely balanced to a bit solventy and thin.  An odd sort of celery-like flavour on the finish.
Pretty decent. Definitely has that Gueuze funk but not over powering. Serving: Bottle

375ml bottle.   Very lightly hazy honey color with a small white head that settles to a small ring, even after an aggressive pour.   The aroma is quite dusty and lactic-sour with some old leather, onion, and lemon.   A touch of barnyard, but definitely not the funkiest gueuze out there.   Dry, peppery, and medium sour in flavor.   Finishes with a sharp, bell pepper kick, but is not very aggressive.   Medium body with light carbonation.   A little flat and flabby overall.   This could have done with some more bubbles.

Bottle to glass.  Initial aroma is semi-dank, mildew and funk over lemon, tart, and sour.  Taste is wonderful chewy sour, funk, lemon, and the slightest bitter sweetness.  Some of the tart notes are really sharp while others seem muffled.  Fair amount of variation in the taste from sip to sip.  Final 3rd of the beer is on the dry side but not so much that my entire palette is cleansed . . . some lingering tart and sugary bitter after the swallow.  I love this style and I love this beer - great stuff!
From a bottle poured a straw color with a small amount of head.  Nice tart flavor with a lingering aftertaste.

9/6/10.  Bottle.  Very orange pour - looks like pumpkin liquer.  The aroma is a little funky, but mainly straight vinegar.  The body is very light which takes away.  This combined with the vinegary acidic flavor makes it seem like sour white wine.

My first beer in Belgium had at Delirium. A ancient looking brew with a rotting old label. Looked like best buy 2027. Pours a cloudy yellow color with a medium white head. The aroma is sweet dry musty yeasty notes. The flavor is great; dry, yeasty, light fruit, pear and apricot, dust and cobwebs. Very easy to drink a 375.
375 ml.  classic light yellow sour earthy gueuze. light head, refreshing, I would definitely seek out again.

A-pours a lighter tranparent amber color with a white fluffy head.

S-the nose offers a light earthy funk, notes of dry dusty library books, sweetness in the back with notes of tart cherry and a light acidity.

T-the taste has a similar profile with a light dusty funk, a little cellar musk, and old library books, this funk evolves into a light sweetness to balance, juicy cherries that have a hint of tartness and very low level of acidity.

M-smooth and creamy up front with a syrupy medium body, a little rougher in the back with a slightly dry finish and a strong well done carbonation.

D-solid beer and probably doesnt get the credit it deserves, it lacks the balance and complexity of some of the better gueuze but is still a tasty beer that is easily enjoyed.

750 ml bottle from a trade with glouglouburb. shared with jsprime. pours slightly hazed golden with a minimal white head. aroma of tart, acidic, woody sour ale. the flavour is similar. classic gueuze in every aspect. thanks for the bottle dany.
7th March 2010. Hazy amber - gold beer, thin white head. Sourish nose. Very sour and dry. Some vinegar and a dash of lemon. Well on the wrong side of too sour for me.

Poured a hazy yellow/amber with almost no head.  Aroma is funky with lemons and sour apples.  Taste is crisp and sour.  This has been blended very well.  The perfect amount of tart to accompany the fruity flavors.  Lemon, apples, and sour flavors dominate.  Aftertaste is sour, but not too sour.  Im not too familiar with the style, but this was a great introduction!

A damn fine beer, I would drink it until my liver gave way. Nothing offensive at all, just beer bliss. Would get again fo sho.
super dry and sour and hints of funk, no vinegar, very drinkable, puckeringly sour at times, maybe best bang for the buck gueze on earth

Bottle. Thanks to Podges beer stall, Chelmsford Summer Beer Festival 2010. Damn I needed a lambic. Peachy golden colour; peaches, cherries, funky elements, low carbanation, something absolutely perfect for a summer English garden, one fantastic lambic. Thanks a lot. I want another one,.

375 ml corked and caged bottle.  Served in a tulip, the beer pours a dark gold/amber color with pretty much no head at all.  No lacing either.  Great aroma, the brew smells like funk, vinegar, lemon zest and tart cherries and apples.  The beer tastes like tart apples/cherries/pears, vinegar, and funk.  Theres also a bit of fruity sweetness noticable too, but the lingering finish is tart.  For the most part the taste is similar to the aroma.  The sour/tartness is very noticable, but not overpowering.  Mouthfeel/body is light/medium, its a bit slick and dry with low carbonation.  Drinkability is good.  I dont know if I could drink more than one bottle of this at a time, but also I dont have any problems finishing the bottle I just drank.  I think this is a good overall brew.  If I was in the mood for a gueuze, I wouldnt have any problem buying this one again.

Bottle.  Aroma has notes of pungent sour fruits, lemons, sweat, vinegar and brine.  Medium orange hue with a small white head that left little lace.  Taste is medium sweet and heavy sour.  Palate is light bodied and thin with an average carbonation.  Finish is astringent and crisp.  A fantastic Gueuze!  Very fruity, thin and crisp with a huge sour bite.  Great!.

head: none 
colour: light amber 
smell : acidic sour , some hops , fruity 
taste: quite a sour start , melts over into a moderate sour/bitterness with a fruit and citric background , end is very dry and carbonation is almost flat

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2012 A: Orange-straw colored body. Very tiny head, quickly receded while leaving just the faintest traces of lacing behind on the glass.
S: Acidic lemon, musty earthy hops, light wheat, and a nice lactic sourness.
T: Bold sour lemons, nice earthy hops, musty wood, a bit orange, and a bold sourness. The flavor profile is more developed than the aroma leads on to.
M: Light-medium bodied. Gentle carbonation. Towards the stronger end of the sour spectrum of gueuzes. Nice and tart and acidic. Refreshingly dry.
O: A very nice gueuze. I think the sourness and the predominantly lemon flavor eventually slows this one down. A good example of the style for sure

750mL at Monks. Pours a clear, deep yellow to orange apple cider color with a dense and temporary white head that is not allowed to stick around from the acids. Awesome cheesy, briny, funky, sweaty nose. Just spot on geuze. Taste is very sour, full of acedic acid, white sushi vinegar, wet leather, spicy oak. It is so sour that it will make you sweat. The briny cheese character feels like youve had ocean water go up your nose and it clears out your sinuses rather forcefully. After a full 750 of this (no one in my group would touch this thing), it becomes pretty lacerative on the palate. But this would happen to just about anyone that tries to put down a 750mL sour bomb like this by themselves. Sometimes I wish it were more subtle and bretty like some Cantillon offerings. But this is so sour and so intense, that it is up my alley. Lovely- great example of a geuze.

Cork and caged bottle from Canals Hainesport bargain bin!! Poured a chill hazed light orange body with a small to average sized creamy white head. Aroma of tart rotten lemons, burnt rubber and vinegar soaked bread. Very lively body with a medium mouthfeel and tight bubbly carbonation. Flavor is tart lemon, green apple skins, barnyard and funk. Really tart and nice.

Bottle bought in Brussels. A bit hzy, orange-peach body with no foam. The aroma is acidic, with peach, cherry and strawberries following you. The first sip is not only sour, but very acidic as well. The taste is oaky though, and the finish is long and fresh.
Bottled 375ml. A great example of the style in my opinion. Strong sourness. I reveled in every sip. Top notch.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2012 Bottle shared by shawnm213- thanks again, Shawn!  Pours a cloudy orange-brown color with a tiny beige head.  Notes of yeast, oak, lactic acid; sour and tart.  The flavor is also sour and tart, with the same notes and some lemon citrus in both as well.  I really just dont know the words to describe this kind of beer.  I really like it, though.  Cant help but keep pulling it up to take another sip.  Medium-bodied, tart, but not overwhelming in the tartness our sour character.  Cool beer. RE-RATE: Sampled two versions at STLWills 30th birthday tasting. One was from 2010, the other from the early 1960s. Yep, you read that right. The 1960s version poured clear gold with no head. Woody, corky, musty, funky, salty aroma. Flavor of a dusty basement, but also solid gueuze characteristics, like oaky funk, leather, lemon, and salt water. Light-medium bodied, with low carbonation and a dusty, musty, tart mouthfeel. Great experience, and held up to be surprisingly drinkable despite 50 or so years on it. As for the newer one, its a very solid up-the-middle gueuze. I clearly didnt know how to rate it in April 2010, but its tart, funky, dry, and really nice overall.
UPDATED: APR 14, 2010 Bottle. Hazy golden colour with small white head. Vinegar in the nose. The flavour is very sour, slightly malty and fruity. Quite sour gueuze.
Bottle. Murky golden with no head. Big funky nose. Apples, peach, wood, vinegar. Acidic taste thats overkill. Acidic and intense sharp finish. Im not a fan.
Golden with a white head. Really sour aroma with notes of dust. Champagne-ish palate. Really sour and surprisingly bitter.

Reddish amber with a very light head. Loud cheesy old socks aroma. Sour crisp snappy beer lets you know youre alive! Each sip is a taste of barrel and time travel as your eyes blink with the sourness. I think Ive developed a twitch in my right eye!
this one wasnt for me. pours hazy gold with no head. aroma is very agressive tartness. drinks heavy with sour/vinegar, crisp citrus, light fruits, very funky and very sour

Bottle at home, 2006-vintage.
Clear amber coloured with a medium sized off white head.
Acidic aroma of wood and barnyard,
Acidic flavour of wood and branyard with notes of bananas.
Tart finish.
One dimenisional like most other hanssen beers.

75 cl. deep golden color, a lot like cider. Controlled aroma, barnyard funk, lemon, a bit of lactic acid, some tannin and stones. Controlled sourness on the tongue, lemon, crystall shards, wood, a bit of funk. Some nice grainy sweetness as well. Very mellow and drinkable. Huge fermentation for a Gueuze--nice! There is also a strange flavor, such as fried scallops, in the long-run after taste.
Sour peachy aoma. Peachy flavour, thick mouthfeel. Hazy orange colour with no head. Go sour beers!!!!

750ml bottle.  no age date on bottle.  just a slight haze in the bronze/gold colored beer that sits under a medium sized fluffy white head.  aroma of white grape juice and a far off funkiness.  flavor is moderate to punchy sour.  white grapes, oak barrel, peaches.  light body.  juicy.  low to medium carbonation.

Hazy orange beer, some sparkling. Quite thick head. The aroma is a bit berryish at  first , somewhat woody and acidic in the finish. Sritzy lemon in the middle. Dry, acidic taste of vomit and barnyard. Quite strong, dry oakiness int the finish with minor bitterness. Sturdy palate is tart. The finsih is delicate but a bit thin. Clearly less dry and acidic, more fruity gueuze. Mellow and quite soft drink.

bottle at chicago sourfest... pours a semi-clear orange brown with a thin soapy white head.... aroma of sharp biting and acidic vinegar... flavors are similar to the nose.  again with the sharp acidity.  pretty nice overall.

Pours light orange with thin white head, aroma is huge sour tart with some lemon.  Taste up front is a bit of citrusy lemon and citrus that turns mouth puckeringly sour and tart with a very dry finish.  Can tell it was aged for a long time, very good sour brew if you want sour!

A: The usual cloudy, sparkling, yellow-gold liquid with a bit of white foam on top that dissipates somewhat quickly.

S: You can tell this one is going to be great just from the nose. Tart lemon and lactic acid, along with a nice musty and earthy quality.

T: This one starts off with a tongue buckling sourness to it. Wonderful lemon and green apple flavors, in terms of the fruit. There is a slight bit of oak and a dry funkiness.

M: Very effervescent and medium in body with that wonderful dryness.

D: Theres only so much of this stuff you can drink before it burns a hole in your stomach, but even then, Id probably keep drinking it. One of the better Gueuzes Ive had, and at the price, you cant beat it.

Bottle from "Completely Non-Epic Gueze Tasting 10". Poured a hazy orange-yellow with little head. Aroma was overwhelmingly funky with wet grass, lemon and cheese. Deliciously sour with hints of orange/lemon zest, and a very dry finish. Carbonation complements the flavor wonderfully.

Bottle from Knightly Spirits.  Bright light orange color, thin head but some foam remains on top until the last drop.  A few whisps of lacing.  This is sour and puckery, light fruits; lemons, grapefruit, peaches, funk and some barrel notes.  A mild burn in the senses.  Drinkable for the style.  Very nice.  If theres such a thing as a bargain Gueze this might be it.

Pours a bubbly, bright orange with essentially no head. Strong aroma. Sour of course, funky yeast, and a strong fruity smell like peaches and pears. Flavor was fairly sweet and wonderfully sour. Made my mouth pucker a little during the first few sips. Palate was nice and fizzy with a lasting sour finish.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2011 Dark gold pour with a minimal head. Aroma has great funk, bubblegum, citrus, hay, straw, tannin, and horseblanket. Flavor is quite woody with more sour funk and a touch of grapefruit and orange rind. Further notes of apricot and peach mixed in with the sour components. Palate is really nice; excellent level of carbonation, and a beautiful dry finish. Damn tasty. 

Rerate 9/26/11- on cask at Pizzeria Paradiso in Dupont. Such a mindblowingly insane experience the second time around. Hugely sour, way more intense than the bottle version that I had, and also had some really intense peaty wood presence; I truly couldnt figure this out. Unlike any other manifestation of a prototypical gueuze. In conclusion, though, I LOVED it. upped the rating from a 3.9 to a 4.3

375mL bottle from Knightly Spirits. Pours a golden with a thin head at first, which fades to nothing. Bubbles coat the inside of the glass. Musty acidic nose, funky, tart lemons, carbonation kicks a tartness that hits high in the nasal passage. Sour, tart, puckering flavor. Very light on the acetic, but loads of lactic acid, gives a hint of puckering fruity sweetness mid after the tart assault and before the dry finish. A little heavier body than some other gueuzes, but still quite light, dry, refreshing and easy to quaff. For the price, this is fantastic.

Light straw pour with a very minimal white head. The aroma quite funky- nectar, bubblegum, farmy horsepen, and oak. The flavor is quite oaky with nice tannin levels, full flavored funk profile, and further bubblegum notes. The palate is full for the style, with excellent acidity, and a puckering dry finish.

Slightly Pink Pour, this beer was of course sour, but what really bothered me is how salty it was. Maybe I got a bad bottle at Knightly Spirits in Orlando, but this guy tasted like someone unscrewed the caps of my salt and pepper shakers and WHAM! there goes my dinner. Cloudy, a little smoky, and not sweet at all.

1pint 12.7oz bottle from Knightly Spirits (I think).  Orange gold pour with a thin white head and minimal lacing.  Typical gueuze aroma of grapes, lemon, oak, sour apple (which all somehow combines to smell like bandaids to me).  Taste is a nice sharp funky white grape that goes to lemon bitter.  Has that sweet funk throughout.  A massive tart, acidic and dry finish.  Harsh tastes that make you pucker. Overall a strange sweet tart goodness.

This is an incredible display of a lambic gueze style. This has sour hints of yeast and barely. The flavor is extremely intense bitters that wow the taste buds and intensive the floral aromas of the hops. I really enjoyed this beer as it was the second gueze I have ever had.
Bottle.Thanks to BrianK for sharing. Golden amber pour with white head. Played pong with this... Easy to drink gueuze despite very sour taste. Full flavored, aged nicely. 04 Vintage I believe.

(Bottle into a tulip glass)  This is my first sample in this style and I loved it!  Poured a deep amber/orange color with only a trace of white head.  Lacing was minimal, but some hung on the glass until the end.  The nose...well all I can describe it as is "earthy"... there is no discernible aroma but the smell was of a muddy creek after a rain, or of that nice wet hay smell on the farm -- very pleasant.  When I tasted, I was shocked at first at how sour this was, as the aromas gave no hint of that.  Very lively carbonation pops a strong lemon on the tongue and complimented my sharp cheddar burger beautifully!

Clear yellow-brown pour with a thin white head.  A few small bubbles throughout.  Woody citrus aroma with lots of acidity.  A touch of vinegar on top.  Bitter earthy flavor with a nice mild tartness.  Herbal grass finish.
Bottle. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Dark yellow colour. Exstremely powerfull sour aroma. Powerfull sour flavor. Long great finish. Oily palate.
Orange and hazy. Has a white head, lasting. Harsh acidic aroma, sulfur-impression too. Solvents, glue. Acidic flavor, heavy. Dry texture.
Medium head with medium duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are sour and cheesy. Nice bitter and sour finish.
Bottle. Unclear orange colour with a small white head. Rich aroma and taste of fruits and citrus with heavy acidic notes. Nice well balanced finish.

750ml corked and caged bottle.  Pours a very hazy, nearly opaque, orange yellow with a big, frothy, white head.  Aroma is very grassy, lemons, grapefruit, musty.  Flavor is BIG on the lactic sourness, strawberries, grass, lemons, a little cheesy, a little funky.  Finish is dry with lasting sourness.  Really good, but be prepared because its also very lactic.

Bottle shared with Brothers Eric & Nathan and Lauren on Christmas Eve. Pours slight cloudy golden with fading bubbly white head. Nose is strong lemon sour and barnyard funk. Taste is sharp biting sour, lemony, barnyard abound. Long sour finish with mouth drying effect. Very refreshing and pleasing for the sour lover. Got my fix. Yum.

From bottle graciously shared by awiseman.  Aroma is bright citrus.  On a side note my mouth is puckering and I havent even tasted it yet.  Appearance is cloudy and golden with a frothy white head.  Well, what can I say about the taste.  Its sour and citrusy, which is perfect really.  Sharp on the front with the citrus coming on the back.  Quite delicious.  Im a big fan of this style.

Pours a cloudy golden orange with a small off white ring, some spotty lacing.  Very tart citrus, horse blanket and dry oak on the nose.  Flavor starts very tart with citrus peel then gives way to horse blanket and oak with a dry, slightly acidic finish.

Yellow brown color with no head. Aroma is nice and funky, some hay, and sourness. Flavor is sour, citrusy, lemon rind and funk. Finishes so clean and nice and dry with some citrus tartness. Bottle of this stuff go down so nicely in an evening. One of my New Years go-tos :)

A: The cork flys out of this baby like the cannonball man at the circus. It pours a lovely orangish red color with a nice tall bubbly head. There are several lines of bubbles rising to the top to keep this active. If it dies down at all just swirl the glass and enjoy the show, reminds me of one of them little glass tornado thingys.

S: Ahh yeah they have brought the funk. Tons of funky aromas here. Overly ripe peach, vinegar, and enough acid to drop the PH in my swimming pool.

T: Tear Jerker bubble gum baby. I like this one. With the first swig you are greeted by a hint of fruity sweetness... Then whoosh you are immediately overtaken by tons of sour and a touch of oak. Acidic bubbles dance in your mouth and down your throat. Fireworks continue to go off as it travels down to your belly. It finishes extra dry and extra sour. Simply Lovely.

M: Literally bursting with sourness. Like sour pop rocks in your mouth.

750 mL bottle from Grape & Gourmet (purchased January 2009).  Golden pour with a foamy white head.  Sour apple cider vinegar aroma.  Very tart lemon flavor.  Lactic aftertaste.  Funky and sour, surely not to everyones liking but I think its great.

Bottle. Pours a nice golden orange. Smallish white head. Disppears pretty quickly leaving some lacing. Aromas of lemon acidity and plenty of barnyard funk. Quite well balanced though. Flavours are quite tart with more of the barnyard funk coming through. Quite dry finish with plenty of acidity giving a very slight mettalic taste. Nice beer

bottle, pours gold with a medium frothy white head.  Strong lemon and wild yeast aroma.  Very fruity with peach and dried apple, some muscat grape and grapefruit.  Really nice and tart, alot more fruity flavor than other gueuzes Ive had.

Cellared less than a year at the brewery.

Slightly hazy orange with a minimal white head.

The aroma has a rather "clean" funkiness (perhaps well-defined is a better word considering the circumstances) of barnyard and mud with some pleasant notes of fruits and lemony acidity. The funkiness gets more pronounced after a while.

The taste is tart and refreshing with a decent amount of funk. Pleasant notes of sour fruits and berries. Hints of oak and grass. The finish is mildly bitter and nicely dry with a faint hint of minerals. Very good.

Moderate body, medium levels of carbonation.

A good one. Very refreshing and fairly complex.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)
Pours hazy orange with a foamy white head. Aroma is vinegar, lemon, lime, and some floral notes. Taste is grain and lemon; prety acidic and refreshing.

Bottle. Pours slight hazy golden coloured with a small lasting egg white head. Aromas of balsamic vinegar, wood, apples, citrus fruit, spices, musty basement and earth. Sour, tart and dry flavour with notes of lemons, spice, wood and apples. Great gueuze - tasty and complex..

Pours a slightly hazy golden yellow color with a two finger frothy, pillowy white head tat slowly fades into a lasting cap. Minimal splotches of soapy lacing.

Earthy funky barnyard aroma with a good bit of estery golden crisp fruit notes. Lots of oak and musty stinky horesblanket blending with crisp light fruits, especially apple and pear. Slightly lactic. The smell of this beer makes my mouth water.

Pretty rtame for the style but still plenty flavorful. Not as funky earthy or acidic as i expected but still enough of the sour tartness and barnyard funk to make it epsecially mouthwatering. Slightly oak with a perfect amount of tart sournes that balances out the sweet estery golden fruit notes. Creamy medium body which again is unusual for the style with a lactic funk. Subtle malty backbone which is more pronounced than most examples of the style.

This beer is very complex and while it has a good bit of barnyard tart funkiness it is not acidic at all as has a lot of complexity, integrating sweet estery light fruit notes, resulting in one of the most drinkable sours Ive had yet. Highly recommended!

(375 ml bottle from Global Beverage) Pours hazy gold-yellow-amber with about a finger of off-white head. Tart, sharp aroma of sour peach and apricot. Mouthfeel soft, lightly stinging, fairly smooth but finely prickly and a bit dryish. Fine, light webby rings of lacing. Flavor of sour and tart peach, apricot and citrus. Has a light woody quality as well although I dont know that this spent anytime on wood. Nice lambic.
Bottle. Clear golden with a steady white head. Acid, fruit, citrus and barnyard in aroma. The flavour is citric, sour acidic, sweet fruity and very dry. Very delicious.

(on bottle) Dark yellow, small white head.  Great sent here; true mould and tart grape, as in Grappa. Rounded malts, with that sour zing of yeast being totally untamed. The beers carbonation is perfect and leaves a last, almost vinegarlike finish, right on the spot.

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2013 375 ml bottle. A hazy dark golden beer, with a large, frothy/fizzy, mostly diminishing white head. The aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain/bread), heavily yeasty (cheese, wet earth/mold/mushrooms, barnyard, leather, dust), with notes of wood and citiric fruits, with a white wine hint. The flavor is moderately sweet, heavily acidic. Medium body, Watery/velvety texture, lively carbonation, dry and long finish with light bitterness. Oustanding rendition, uber-yeasty, yet not super estreme. Drinkable, to the contrary. Great for a hot summer evening.

375 mL bottle at Monks on 10/4/09.  Pours a clear dark golden with a little white head.  Aroma dominated by lemon and grapefruit.  Solid sour tartness, but not to the point of puckering the cheeks.  Pretty decent gueze, especially given the price.

375ml bottle.  Hazy yellowly color with just a crown of lace around the edges, lacking in carbonation.  Super funky barnyard smell combined with burnt rubber.  Makes normal people cringe and recoil (I had my friend smell it who doesnt like beer like this and his nose crinkled in confusion and horror).  The taste is that of barnyard hay, burnt rubber, old gym socks and subtle citrus crisp.  The finish is a super funky lingering taste that makes me feel like I ate a stink bomb...I love it.  As the beer warms up I taste granny smith apples.  More carbonation would make it just that much better.

37,5 cl bottle. Pours dark golden. Big white head. Lemon flavor, allthough little bit to sharp for me. This was my second Oude Geuze, i prefer the Girardin Oude Geuze White label. But still, nice beer!

04 Bottle from the First Annual Chicago Sour Tasting, thanks to Andrew. Golden pour with creamy off white head. Great aroma of wood,  white grape, mild barn yard funk. Bright sharp tartness leads off the flavor, followed by gentle woodiness, nice tannins. Nice dry finish. Very delicious.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2010    bottle. pours a clear golden orange with a medium, soapy white head.  Aroma has notes of lemon,  grass, wood, perfume, and a pleasant basement horseblanket  funkiness to it.  Flavor has notes of lemongrass against a backdrop of horseblanket funk.  nice lemony, barnyard tartness.  Nice and dry.  Awesome balance.  A standard and  great example of the style.  Easily one of my favorite beers.  Always enjoy drinking this.   Ive  had some old bottles of this that were out of this world, but some new bottles have been so so.

(bottle) pours a hazy orange colour with a frothy white head. aroma has lots of citrus and funk, with dry spices and hints of grass and roses. flavour is mildly funky, with some sweet bready notes and a mildly sour finish, wonderfully balanced. medium body and carbonation.

Pours hazy orange with a lacy medium head.  Arom is...mmmm....gueze.  Big lemon drop note with a fair helping of sour funk and a slight burlap note.    Flavor is tart lemon, sour grapes,  dusty cobwebs, a bit of earth, some burlap, wood, and a lemon drop aftertaste.  Exactly what I wanted from this one, no surprises.  A classic example of the style, which I admittedly like very much..
Initial palate shock as i have nver had a gueuze before. Aroma and taste is similar to that of a white wine. great sour flavor...lacie white head. delicious sour beer with great mouthfeel.
Foam Rangers tasting. Gold color with average head. Barn-y funk with citrus and oak. Much tart up front. Flavor is sour citrus with great acidity and clean finish. Solid beer.

A bit on the expensive side...I know thats got nothing to do with the rating, but worth noting.  An orange-yellow color, with a very thin white head, and soft carbonation.  Still, mouth feel is sharp and a bit of a burn going down.  I get strong grapefruit sourness and acid, so thats probably the culprit.  Almost a sour apple cider, verging on a cider vinegar flavor.  Great beer to have tried, but not really one of my favorites.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2011 Bottle at Plan B. 
It pours a hazy yellow with a big fluffy white head.
Aroma is strong and dry with notes of humid cellar, citrus, apple and sesame.
The flavour is dominated by lemon and sesame with notes of apple and wood ending in a lemon bitter after taste. 

Old 1950-1960, 80cl bottle to celebrate the completion of my master studie and a new government in DK! :-D Big courtesy to Raf (Pallieter85)!!
Shared with Trine, Mikkels, SIlja, RangledeFreak and Andreasen11. 
Pours lovely golden/amber with not head. removing the cork was quite a task, as it felt totally apart but left a small fizz when breaking its seal. It had a nice and smooth aroma revealing its an old and slightly oxidised bottle. 
The taste was still very acidic with earthy notes and a hint of cork. 
Not that it has turned bad but I like it better when its not that old. Anyway it was astonishing to try and what a gem! 
Thanks again Raf!

Pours a slightly hazy golden with off white head. Aroma is an explosion of sour funk, tart, citrus, lemon, spice, apple, dried fruit. Gueuuuuze.  Taste is similar, so much fruit sourness. A great Lambic Gueuze.

750ml shared at Scottyps housewarming tasting.  Holy shit.  I can feel the enamel leaving my teeth as I write this.  Clear golden straw pour with good white head.  Nose is the sour gym socks that I have come to love from this style. Flavor is like that of a lemon warhead.  I am starting to warm up to this style,

Pours a lasting ring of off-white head.  Aromas of stank, funk, sour, and bubblegum.  Flavor is zest, bubblegum, and sour, like warhead candy.  Enamel is being stripped from my teeth by this delicious, mouth-puckering brew.

Bottle shared with Savvy1982... Thanks Kyle! Pours a hazy yellow with no head. Aroma is complex and sour wioth earthy and soapy notes. Very nice acidic and musty flavor. Nice mouth feel. Nice beer... Now the heart burn kicks in and ends our gueuze tasting early. But the best of the lot we tried back to back.

04 Bottle from the First Annual Sour Tasting, thanks to Andrew.  Pours a clear copper yellow with a thin off white head.  Hay citrus, light funk and mild earthiness that makes me think faded hops.  Tart citrus flavors, hay, earthy and almost leathery in texture.  Tart and acidic, this really comes together well.  Nice gueuze.

Bottle. Pours hazy orange with a thin skim of white foam. Ropey lacing at best. Nose is sour and spicy; loads going on here. Blackberry, blueberry, raspberry, apples, spice, oak, must, damp earth, funk, sweaty horseblanket. Tight and fresh, with plenty of salty lemons and seaspray, iodine, tour peachskin. Wow! Cracking good! Palate isnt quite as intense as the aroma, but is very well balanced, and quite sour for a Gueuze. Incredibly nice.

(Bottle) Pours light hazy golden with small to medium-sized head. The aroma is big time bretty with tones of sweaty horse/horse blanket and barnyard. Very citric with notes of lemon and lime alongside a light fruitiness. Undertones of dust, saw dust, cheese and wood. The flavour is very dry, tart and acidic with tones of horse blanket, barnyard, wood, citrus, fruits and vinegar. Medium carbonation. Near medium bodied. A brett bomb!
A 0.75L bottle shared at Pikkulintu. Pale head. Mild nose with peach notes. Golden yellow clear colour. Slightly sour and grapefruity taste. Some hints of apricot in the taste.

April(?) 2008:  Shiny new copper color, hazy complexion, bitterness in the middle and finish, very acidic and tart flavor = Hanssens Oude Gueuze.  Again, this beer is good, but beyond my realm of true understanding.
1 pt. 9.4 fl. oz. bottle (Alc. 6% Vol.) shared by Tmoney99.  Thanks Tom!  Rating #480 for this beer.
Hazy golden with very slight white head.  Aroma of citrus, lemon and grapefruit.  Sourish taste, good body, dry finish.  Nice.

Corked 37.5cl bottle from De Bierkoning, Amsterdam. A fizzy amber geuze beer with a minimal short-lasting white head. Prominent aromas of citrus fruits (oranges and lemons) with a hint of damp wood. The flavour is tart lemony sourness which seems to get sweeter and smoother as your palate adjusts to it. The damp woodiness is in there as well. Finishes dry and tart. Medium bodied with a fullish mouthfeel. Probably the most complex and sour geuze I have tried so far. Not sure I like it as much as the others.

Bottle during the first annual Chicago Sour Tasting.  Bottled in 04 thanks to Andrew.  Clear amber/orange with small white head.  Aroma is wood, sour.  Flavor is sour, wood, pretty sour and high acidity.  Medium to light and high acidity burn.  Solid, dry but very acidic.

bottle @ Poechenkeller.
dark orange pour, small white head.
very sour, lemon peel mostly, with slight funk.
tasted like easting a lemon peel -- not in a bad way though. a bit of wood and other fruit as it warms.
slick body, lots of carbonation.
slightly vinegar-y, but good.
Clear goldblond coloured beer with medium carbonation and almost no head. Sour aroma with bits of fruit. Full sour palate. Finish is sour ending smooth. Good one, liked it more than Oud Beersel.
gold blond coloured body with a white head a sourig fruity aroma a sourig fruity little sweet taste with a sourig bitter finish

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2012 Bottle with a yellowish tinted label. Pours with. After seeing some other Hanssens destroy their corks, I would say that this is a newer bottle. Pours a hazed gold with a minimal white head. Aroma from a far is damp forest, cheese, lemon soak wood, and upon closer inspection dirty socks, lemon, various herbs and spices, horse. On the funkier rather than the sour side of Gueuzes sour wise. Floral and earthy as it warms. Taste is sour with tons of lacto, pineapple, and a bit of wood. A bit of lemon rind sourness. Light in both wood and fruitiness. Stomach acid similar to other Hanssens lambics. Some what creamy carbonation for a lambic. Sour mouthpuckering mouthfeel.  Also had to try a bottle estimated to be around 50 years old. Flat, but with a rich funk and acidity that held up shockingly well over the years.
Im a huge fan of guezes but this way to sour without being rewarding.  Dark straw color with a disappointing head.  Taste is just over powering fruit and sourness.

375ml bottle, 2000 vintage from Cracked Kettle.

Pours clear amber without any head. 

Wet grass, fruity and sour.
Hazy gold foamy head. Cheese, funk and barnyard. Flavor is extremely sour! Great flavor with nice syrupy mouthfeel.

750ml Bottle:  Tart aroma of lambic, oak, wood, light funk, light vinegar, acid, and epoxy.  Poured orange in color with a small, white head that lasted throughout.  Very hazy.  Not sparkling.  Flavor is medium tart and heavily sweet.  Tastes of lambic, wood, berries, fruit, oak, slight caramel, slight vinegar, acid, citrus, and slight funk.  Light to medium body.  Dry texture.  Average to lively carbonation.  Tart, sweet, wood, and fruit finish is dry.

Pours a golden amber with virtually no head.  aroma is a little funky with tart fruit and some hay aromas.  flavor is sweet and tart and includes some hay, vinger, oak, chesse, yeast.  the fruity flavors include tart apple, lemon, and orange.  has a medium mouthfeel with a crisp and dry finnish with a aftertaste that tastes like orange juice.  I enjoyed this one very much.

Bottle (2000 - 9 years old). Ap: Golden amber. No head. Looks funky. Ar: Sweet actually, some kind of sour bitterness (vineager maybe). Fla: Sour red berries. Incredible fruity. No real tartness in the finish, some kind of bitterness though. Ov: Quite sophisticated. Not as funky as one would think (maybe due to the ageing).

Medium cloudy amber, no head.  Aroma is weird like sour bandaids but flavor is surprisingly sweeter but still tart.  Flavor: sweet hay that horses have walked all over with poopy horse-shoes but weirdly ina very delicious and refreshing way.  Crisp mouthfeel and slightly dry finish with an aftertaste like orange juice.

Bottle. The Rover. Gothenburg. Hazy golden orange colour with a white head. Aroma: Bretty funky cheese up front, also some sourness and lemons. Taste: Heavy sourness and tartness, sour green apples, lemons. Also some funk, cheese and oak. But mostly very sour. Much more sour then the aroma indicates. Great if you are a fan of sour beers.

[2109-20090421] 12.7floz bottle. Mild citrus orange rind and burnt popcorn yeast aroma. Hazy, light orange body with a medium-lasting creamy off-white head. Fruity orange peel yeast and mild popcorn flavour. Quite sour medium body. Very enjoyable, out of the blue.
(c/o blankboy, w/ him, garthicus, jerc)

Bottle, from Johns Grocery, Iowa City, Iowa. Oh my my. It has been far too long since Ive had a proper, bracingly sour beer. When I bought this, the guy behind the counter said, "Just so you know--this isnt a sweet lambic." Bless your heart kid, I know. Shiny gold pour, good persistent white head. Oh wow, what a beautiful aroma. The cool earthy smell of walking through a field of tall grass on an early fall morning. Fresh cracked black pepper, preserved lemons, a whole lumberyard full of old wood, and tingling on the edges, a cheerful little candied apple note. Flavor is bracing lemon sourness, full and pleasing but by no means the enamel dissolving acid bombs of some of Cantillons more aggressive blends. Enthusiastic and all-together pleasing, wool and gentle oak notes. I try to restrain evil-genius-type laughter as I survey the 2/3s of a bottle still remaining after typing out this rating. Mine! All mine!! Muhahahahaha! (In my own defense, I actually ended up sharing an entire glass with Traci.)

smells sour and funky, taste of malt vinegar, it gives of some soft carbonation.
its hard to enjoy Gueze when you dont appreciate it.

The aroma is sour and sweet with malty, fruity, and funky elements with what seems to be a urinal cake. The appearance is golden with an average head for the style. The flavor is like the aroma with a malty and tart finish. The palate is average. Overall this just isnt my thing.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2016 750ml  ; In a Cantillon flute this is a  gueuze that intertwines  complexity with ease of drinkibability even more so than any Ive sampled  in the style.  id reflect it is  somewhere in the neighbourhood  of being relaxed in character  but still retains thet intense potent  uncompromising Gueuze texture  ..It is the most refreshing beer you could seek.. bone dry , notes of lemon , zest , oak depth , with an awesome complexity that morphs into a cheesy rich tart  salad dressing like finish. Stunning!!! .

750 ml bottle into tumbler; purchased at the venerable Discount Liquor in Milwaukee.  Head is restrained for a gueuze, not as bilious as expected, but produces a wonderful doily lacing.  Funk dispersing all over the air around the beer (accented with white grape tartness thats a bit dark; reminds me a little of black label Girardin).  And then: bam.  Nicely aggressive acidity attacks the under-tongue (just like a gueuze should).  Finish is bretty funk with lingering juicy fruitiness and a thin layer of confectioners sugar sweetness, and the acidity still attacking the glands in waves.  Wonderful gueuze that hits all the sweet spots.

My bottle (12.7oz) shared with garthicus, jerc & mabel -- c/o GregClow. Pours a hazy orange with a large diminishing fluffy white head. Nice aroma! Sour, funky and yeasty along with sharp spices and citrus. Flavour of tart citrus, sour fruit, light spices and some funkyness -- it tingles the tongue. Medium bodied. Great stuff!

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2010 Cloudy golden in color, little to no head. Flavor is sour, of course, but crisp and dry, well balanced against citrus elements. Lovely, lingering sour aftertaste. A little more assertive than other gueuzes Ive tried, but still very nice.

Cask @ Map Room. Hazy, greenish yellow w/ limpid clear head/bubbly; heavy notes of green peas and nutty Brie w/ wood; peas and lactic, woody acidity in flavor; very earthy and ends sour. Complex and satisfying. Wish it were a shade more vinegar-y.

(Bottle, 0.75 l -- BBE 2024, at Pikkulintu, Helsinki, on 2009-04-26 -- shared with JK54B, thanks!) Golden and hazy. Small white head. Sourness, fruitiness and little bit of cowhouse in aroma. Medium bodied and dry palate with medium carbonation. Tartness, fruitiness, lightly sweetness, sourness, wood and lightly bitterness in taste. Sour and lightly bitter aftertaste.
pours a hazy straw color. Smells sour, acidic and cheesey hops. Flavor is acid, vinegar, sour funk. Some tart apple and slight citrus. Awesome gueuze and generally underappreciated.

Pours a slightly hazy peachy copper color with huge soda bubbles and a medium thick white frothy head that fades into a small froth.  Aroma is fruity, tangy sour, yeasty, dusty, lemon, not too extreme.   Flavor is fuller than most gueuzes, maltier, leaves some metallic taste on the lips, sour with an acidic finish, very very sour, lemon, super mouth puckering, quite sweet as well.  Sugary aftertaste.  Yup, starting to get a good amount of vinegar now... especially in the finish.  Medium bodied, very sharp sparse carbonation, syrupy finish.  Really great beer but a little off in certain directions making it not the easiest of assertive lambics to drink.

Deep golden bodied with a thin white head.  Barnyard funk aroma.  Some sour apple and lemon.  Fairly puckering sour, but not overly done.  A good example.  Ive never been a huge sour fan, but Im starting to find out that I dig the aroma on this style almost more than the flavor itself.

2009-04-21. Murky golden-pastel yellow, modest off-white head. (3+) Funky aroma creeps across the room to meet you. Good amount of funk, light hay and barnyard touches. (7+) Light lemon seeds in the flavour, funk is a bit softer than in the aroma but still there. Pretty sour overall, acidic finish with more lemon seed, and a touch of lemon rind. (7+) Average palate is pleasantly carbonated. Not as complex as some but a rather good lambic. Bottle shared by Blankboy
0.375l - This is the finest lambic Ive had.  Still had the wild, uncontrolled power thats a hallmark of the style, but this was far more approachable.  Sour from the nose on, but didnt crush you.
Aroma is a musty and dusty sour lemon, with some dried grass.  Flavors are sour and tart, with lemons and other citrus.  This is a great beer, made even better by the relatively low pricetag.

This is, as Jakebra would say, a danky. Crushed with my girlfriend. Light orange pour with nice white head. Funky, sour, acidic aroma. Very sour flavor, Lemon, acid, wood, funk. Fruity, puckering, mouthwatering. Refreshing, effervescent mouthfeel. Deliciously awesome.

Bottle.  Pours an opaque orange with a medium white head that fades down quickly.  Light lacing, and little bits of sediment in the glass. Piles of wine cork funk, acid, and hay.  Medium bodied and sour from the start hitting the front of the tongue sharply before moving to the sides of the mouth with a nice puckering sourness.  Nice crisp acid.  Finishes tart and acidic, but very earthy and funky.
Son, a woman is like a beer. They smell good, they look good, youd step over your own mother just to get one! But you cant stop at one. You wanna drink another woman!

Bottle very young.  Pours an orange golden body with a fizzy white head.   Notes of lemon, balsamic, acetic and lactic acid moderately acidic.  Some light wood and leather.  Ill take the kriek instead.

375ml bottle. Pours a crystal clear, bright orange body with lots of initial rising carbonation. Thin, fizzy, loud, white head that leaves a good amount of runny, soapy lacing. Aroma is sweet and sour fruits (apples and grapefruits mostly), acidic vinegar, dry wood, and champagne. Very strong. I dont get the cheese that some others have noted, but I am a novice when it comes to this style. Flavor is initially sour, but really mellows out and shows a light maltiness through the finish. Lots of citric flavors up front that diminish smoothly into the finish, but remain present. Theres an ever present tartness that Im liking because it never gets lip smacking tart. A light woody note at first and a subtle drying finish. The lingering flavor is a mix between an earthy funk and sour tart. Palate is light to medium and surprisingly has a flat carbonation. Overall, Im not very experienced with rating this style of beer, but this one seems to be pretty flavorful and well balanced. It stays sweet and equally sour without ever leaning too much towards one or the other. A good introduction.

From reading some of the review here, it seems that the quality varies greatly from one bottle to the next. Mine poured a slightly cloudy blonde with a thick creamy head. There was some bottle stink at first when I opened the bottle, but after that the aroma was quite nice. Malty, and a little bit fruity. The flavor is where this all falls apart. It is incredibly vinegary, like an old kombucha. Im not sure if I can finish the bottle. I probably wont.

(Big bottle from Pelgrim) Aroma of old cheese. No head but troubled golden color. Really nice raw geuze taste with a refined sour and bitter palate. Overall a nice geuze, but nothing all too special at that.

Cask at Map Room. Pours a golden honey color. fizzy disappearing head. Nose is moderately funky with vinegar and lactic dominating, minimal brett. Taste is pretty tart and grass, cutting away to a very raw grain taste. It is pretty one dimensional and Im really not impressed.

The last beer I drank at beer week.  Dead flat in the mouth, almost no head, almost no hops ... an aged gueuze.  Funky smell, moderate complexity.  More detail:  Looks just like a gueuze ... hazy gold, no head, no lace ... not pretty.  Mouth of a queuze ... no carbonation, almost dead flat.  Nose of a gueuze ... not supposed to be nice and, I guess, its not.  Funky.  Taste is interesting and moderately complex, citrus and sour, but not really complex enough for interest to outweigh intrinsic gueuze nastiness.

Date: 19/1/09
Beer info: Bottled in green 375ml corked bottle 6.0% abv BB 07/08/2027

Sampling Notes:
Served chilled in pilsner glass.
Decent pop upon uncorking, pours a hazy gold body with a bit of white foam that eventually dies down into a dense ring.
Vinegary nose, gets right up into the nostrils, some oakiness and sherry-nuances come with it, big minerally saltiness, sour/fermenting apple and lemon.
Plenty of acetic acidity on the tongue, goes hand-in-hand with the lively carbonation and light body for a serious mouth puckering sensation.
Balsamic vinegar aplenty on the body, green apple, soggy wood, sour grapes, grapefruit with an underlying grainy, honey sweetness adding a small bit of balance.
Doesnt seem as complex as previous ones, still amazing and a journey within itself, but somehow not as refined and coherent...if that makes any sense!

Aroma  7/10
Appearance  3/5
Flavour  7/10
Palate  4/5
Overall  14/20

750ml bottle at Novare Res.
Pours a slightly cloudy golden color with a vanishing white head.  Aroma of funk, yogurt, and cheese.  Flavor is tart, sour, with a note of yogurt/cheese like flavor.  Extemely acidic even by lambic standards. Gave me a sore stomach, i enjoyed it a lot, but the aftermath kind of ruined it.

375 ml corked bottle kindly provided by Beer2000. A coarse  fingerthick big-bubbled near-white head upon a slightly hazed orangey-golden body.  A minty, light acidic fruity sourness in the aroma. Taste starts tart  and citric, followed by a rustic, sour berry/sweaty horse flavor.  Notes of cheese, wood and mouldy cellar. Tart and fruity-acidic finish. A very nice palate cleanser, still a notch too challenging for my tastebuds.

Pours a hazy dark gold with a pillowy white head. Sour apple, white vinegar and sour funk aroma. Taste is light and sour, bracing and slightly fruity. Very sour, tart and funky, yet easy drinking. Good gueuze.

From green 37.5 ml bottle, pours bubbly and straw-colored. Aroma of durian fruit with flavor of fermented soy beans, rotten apples and limbuger cheese. Finish is green apple and kimchi. Startling style.
37,5 cl bottle. Really lemony, little carbonation, nice acid touch. Good gueuze.

375ml bottle $6.99. beautiful orange with a short foam atop, then not even one bubble. It smells like the slightest hint of funky cheese, lemons, dusty boxes. It tastes sour, citrus, lemons, good gueuze. The mouthfeel seemed a little thin at first, but overall it was adequate.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-06-2008 00:44:28

Bottle pours cloudy amber color with white head.  Has aroma that is lemon and funk.  Flavor is acidic, tart, lemon, wood, funk, and makes me pucker.  Mouthfeel is highly carbonated.  Overall a solid brew.
